20101226160007.000|20101226160008.000|TR0|HOWARD KURTZ, CNN ANCHOR:  It's been a 
20101226160008.000|20101226160010.000|TR0|tumultuous year from the Tea Party revolt 
20101226160010.000|20101226160012.000|TR0|to the tax cut compromise, from the Gulf 
20101226160012.000|20101226160014.000|TR0|oil spill to the so-called Manhattan 
20101226160014.000|20101226160016.000|TR0|mosque, from the Wikileaks uproar to this 
20101226160016.000|20101226160018.000|TR0|week's repeal of "Don't Ask, Don't Tell."
20101226160018.000|20101226160020.000|TR0|
20101226160020.000|20101226160022.000|TR0|How did journalists fare in covering 
20101226160022.000|20101226160024.000|TR0|politicians from Barack Obama to Sarah 
20101226160024.000|20101226160026.000|TR0|Palin and media figures from Rick Sanchez 
20101226160026.000|20101226160028.000|TR0|to Juan Williams? Did the news business 
20101226160028.000|20101226160029.000|TR0|sink further into superficiality and 
20101226160029.000|20101226160031.000|TR0|sensationalism? We'll take an in-depth 
20101226160031.000|20101226160033.000|TR0|look.
20101226160033.000|20101226160035.000|TR0|
20101226160035.000|20101226160037.000|TR0|There's never been a television career 
20101226160037.000|20101226160039.000|TR0|quite like it.  Larry King changed the 
20101226160039.000|20101226160041.000|TR0|nature of broadcasting during his 25-year 
20101226160041.000|20101226160043.000|TR0|run at CNN, chatting up the famous and the 
20101226160043.000|20101226160045.000|TR0|notorious, but also drawing criticism for 
20101226160045.000|20101226160047.000|TR0|his laid-back approach.  Did that bother 
20101226160047.000|20101226160049.000|TR0|him? And did declining ratings force him 
20101226160049.000|20101226160050.000|TR0|to give up his show? We'll talk to the man 
20101226160050.000|20101226160052.000|TR0|behind the oversized mike.
20101226160052.000|20101226160054.000|TR0|
20101226160054.000|20101226160056.000|TR0|I'm Howard Kurtz, and this is RELIABLE 
20101226160056.000|20101226160058.000|TR0|SOURCES.  "Larry King Live" began right 
20101226160058.000|20101226160100.000|TR0|here on this set in a nearby building in 
20101226160100.000|20101226160102.000|TR0|Washington back when Ronald Reagan was 
20101226160102.000|20101226160104.000|TR0|president.  It was a bit of an oddity at 
20101226160104.000|20101226160106.000|TR0|first, a radio show with callers on 
20101226160106.000|20101226160108.000|TR0|television.
20101226160108.000|20101226160110.000|TR0|
20101226160110.000|20101226160112.000|TR0|It was stocked with celebrities, but 
20101226160112.000|20101226160113.000|TR0|gradually became a forum for politicians 
20101226160113.000|20101226160115.000|TR0|and presidents as well.  I had my share of 
20101226160115.000|20101226160117.000|TR0|appearances on this set during the mellow 
20101226160117.000|20101226160119.000|TR0|drama of the Clinton years and as a media 
20101226160119.000|20101226160121.000|TR0|critic, I studied Larry's ability to talk 
20101226160121.000|20101226160123.000|TR0|to Paris Hilton or Mick Jagger one day and 
20101226160123.000|20101226160125.000|TR0|Al Gore or George Bush the next.
20101226160125.000|20101226160127.000|TR0|
20101226160127.000|20101226160129.000|TR0|Over the years, the King program became 
20101226160129.000|20101226160131.000|TR0|part of the fabric of American culture.
